questions.text: A 36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being involved in a motor vehicle collision. She is alert, awake, and oriented. There is no family history of serious illness and her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.0°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 102/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows ecchymoses over the trunk and abdomen. A FAST scan of the abdomen is negative. An x-ray of the chest shows no fractures. A contrast-enhanced CT scan of the chest and abdomen shows a 4-cm sharply defined liver mass with a hypoattenuated central scar. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Focal nodular hyperplasia is a common benign liver tumor usually found incidentally on imaging in women between the ages of 20–50. Unlike hepatic adenomas, FNH lesions are generally stable and are rarely complicated by spontaneous rupture and hemorrhage. As a result, they are treated conservatively if patients are asymptomatic. Follow-up imaging at 3 and 6 months is generally recommended to confirm the stability of the lesions, after which no further imaging is required.
Image Description:

CT abdomen (A. without contrast; B: arterial phase; C: venous phase; D: delayed phase)

A nearly isoattenuating mass (green overlay) on the unenhanced image is hyperattenuating relative to surrounding liver on the artierial phase image. It becomes less conspicuous in the portal venous phase and isoattenuating in the delayed phase. A hypoattenuating central scar (red overlay) visible on the arterial and venous phase images becomes hyperattenuating on the delayed phase image as a result of delayed contrast washout from the scar.

The above CT features are typical of focal nodular hyperplasia.

LK: left kidney; P: pancreas; RK: right kidney

B) INCORRECT:

Biopsy of the mass may be performed if the diagnosis remains unclear after imaging or if the patient has a history of neoplasm. However, a sharply defined mass with a hypoattenuated central scar on CT is consistent with FNH, which has no malignant potential. A biopsy is unnecessary in a patient with no prior cancer history.

C) INCORRECT:

Although patients with hepatomegaly and splenomegaly should avoid contact sports to minimize the risk of rupture, FNH is not known to enlarge the liver or the spleen.

D) INCORRECT:

Although patients with FNH who take oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) tend to have larger, more vascular tumors, the risk of hemorrhage is low. In contrast, patients on OCPs with hepatic adenomas are at an increased risk of hemorrhage and, for this reason, should discontinue OCP therapy. Patients with FNH who do not desire to get pregnant may continue taking OCPs until they wish to conceive.

E) INCORRECT:

For symptomatic cystic tumors, percutaneous aspiration may serve as both a diagnostic and therapeutic intervention. However, this patient is asymptomatic and imaging suggests FNH rather than a cystic mass.

F) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection of liver masses may be considered for tumors that have a high risk of rupture or bleeding (e.g., hepatic adenomas > 5 cm), solitary symptomatic tumors, or suspected malignancy. This patient does not have any symptoms related to the liver mass and FNH was diagnosed with relative certainty.
questions.hint: This patient has a 4-cm liver mass with a central hypoattenuated scar on a CT scan, which is diagnostic of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH).

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She was treated for a urinary stone 1 year ago with medical expulsive therapy. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive pill that she has been taking for 12 years. She appears healthy. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count, serum creatinine, and electrolytes are within the reference range. Urinalysis is within normal limits. An ultrasound of the abdomen shows a well-demarcated hyperechoic 3 cm (1.2 in) hepatic lesion. A contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen shows a well-demarcated 3-cm hepatic lesion with peripheral enhancement and subsequent centripetal flow followed by rapid clearance of contrast. There is no hypoattenuating central scar. In addition to stopping the oral contraceptive pill, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transcatheter-arterial embolization is recommended for patients with HAs who are symptomatic or whose lesions are > 5 cm in diameter because of the higher risk of hemorrhage and malignant conversion of HA to hepatocellular carcinoma. The procedure involves inserting coils and/or particulates into the vessels that supply the adenoma, thereby inducing ischemia, necrosis, and involution of the lesion. Recent studies have also found that embolization works especially well for multifocal HAs in patients who are not good candidates for extensive surgery, as well as for patients with actively bleeding lesions. This patient has an asymptomatic lesion that is < 5 cm; therefore, a more conservative course of management is recommended.

In patients with HAs who are pregnant or planning to become pregnant, embolization or radiofrequency ablation of lesions > 2 cm is recommended prior to the second trimester, as the clinical course of HAs during pregnancy is unpredictable and spontaneous hemorrhage carries significant risk for the mother and fetus.

B) INCORRECT:

Percutaneous liver biopsy is recommended to confirm the diagnosis if imaging is unclear or if hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is suspected. On Doppler ultrasound, HCC shows significant arterial blood supply and neovascularization around a round mass with irregular boundaries. On CT, HCC shows a hypodense lesion with irregular borders and possible local invasion. This patient has imaging findings that are consistent with HA; for this reason, a liver biopsy is not indicated at this time.

C) CORRECT:

The first step in managing HAs is to stop oral contraceptives (OCPs) and anabolic steroids and remove any hormone-containing IUDs, all of which can increase the size of the tumor. In female patients, an asymptomatic HA < 5 cm in diameter, as seen here, can be managed conservatively because it is unlikely to undergo rupture or malignant transformation. However, some HAs have been known to increase in size following discontinuation of OCPs or steroids; thus, follow-up CT/MRI with contrast at 6-month intervals for 2 years is strongly recommended. Once serial monitoring over this period has shown that the HA size is stable, imaging may be conducted annually. Surgical resection is recommended in female patients who present with symptoms (e.g., upper abdominal pain, fullness, nausea) and/or a tumor size of > 5 cm as well as in male patients irrespective of tumor size because of an increased risk of malignant transformation.

D) INCORRECT:

Radiofrequency ablation (RFA) may be considered as an alternative treatment for symptomatic patients with HAs whose lesions are < 3 cm in diameter and who are unwilling to undergo or have contraindications for surgery. This patient, however, is asymptomatic and requires different management at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

Given the increased risk of spontaneous hemorrhage and possible malignant transformation to hepatocellular carcinoma in larger HA lesions, surgical resection is recommended for lesions that are > 5 cm in diameter. Surgical resection is also recommended for lesions that are symptomatic. In patients with small tumors within the anterolateral liver segments or patients who have pedunculated tumors, laparoscopic resection may be an option. The majority of tumors, however, require a larger incision with local resection or segmental partial lobectomy. Given that this patient's asymptomatic lesion is < 5 cm, surgical management is not indicated at this time.
questions.hint: This patient is a young woman on the oral contraceptive pill who has a 3-cm hepatic mass. Imaging shows benign findings of peripheral enhancement, rapid clearance of contrast, and no central scar. Considered together, her history and imaging findings make a hepatic adenoma (HA) the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of mild right upper abdominal pain. She has not had any fevers, chills, or weight loss. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. Medications include transdermal estrogen, which she recently started taking for symptoms related to menopause. Abdominal examination shows no abnormalities. Ultrasonography of the liver shows a well-demarcated, homogeneous, hyperechoic mass surrounded by normal liver tissue. A biopsy of the lesion would put this patient at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hepatic hemangioma (HH) is a benign tumor composed of cavernous vascular spaces of variable size that are lined by flat endothelial cells. HHs are most common in women between the ages of 30–50 years and may enlarge in response to elevated estrogen levels (e.g., due to pregnancy, hormonal therapy). Most HHs are asymptomatic and diagnosed incidentally on imaging. Because the tumor is highly vascular, biopsy carries a high risk of severe hemorrhage in patients with HHs and is not recommended unless the diagnosis is uncertain.
Image Description:

Ultrasound liver (transverse plane)

A homogeneous hyperechoic lesion (green overlay) with a well-defined margin and no hypoechoic halo can be seen. There is slight posterior acoustic enhancement (white area). This appearance is characteristic of a hemangioma.

Most hepatic hemangiomas are hyperechoic. However, they can appear hypoechoic, particularly when on a background of hyperechoic hepatic steatosis. If surrounded by a hypoechoic halo, a hyperechoic hepatic lesion must be considered suspicious for malignancy.

PV: hepatic portal vein

B) INCORRECT:

Biliary peritonitis occurs when bile leaks out of the gallbladder or bile ducts and can occur due to inadvertent penetration of the biliary tract during a liver biopsy. Although this is a possible complication of liver biopsy for any condition, it is extremely rare and thus does not present the complication with the greatest risk for this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Biopsy of an intrahepatic abscess (pyogenic liver abscess or amebic liver abscess) risks spreading the infectious focus into the abdominal cavity and bloodstream and should only be performed when laboratory studies and imaging are inconclusive. Although RUQ pain is a common manifestation of liver abscess, most patients also present with fever or other systemic complaints. Ultrasonography of a liver abscess would show poorly demarcated, fluid-filled, hypoechoic lesion(s) within the hepatic parenchyma with surrounding edema and hyperemia, rather than the findings seen here.
Image Description:

Ultrasound abdomen (liver; left: color Doppler, right: contrast-enhanced ultrasound)

A multiseptated hepatic lesion with an anechoic fluid center (left image) shows no vascular enhancement on color Doppler. The necrotic center also does not enhance on contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS; right image), although enhancement of the septae and surrounding parenchyma on CEUS increases the conspicuity of the lesion.

D) INCORRECT:

Biopsy of a malignant hepatic lesion (e.g., hepatocellular carcinoma) can seed tumor cells throughout the track of the biopsy needle, risking metastatic spread. Although HCC may manifest with nonspecific RUQ pain, as seen in this patient, ultrasonography would typically show an ill-defined mass with irregular borders and variable echogenicity due to areas of necrosis and calcification. Furthermore, HCC is unlikely in this healthy woman without any significant past medical history.
Image Description:

Ultrasound abdomen (liver; transverse plane) of a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma

A large heterogeneous mass (green hatched overlay) in the left hepatic lobe proved to be hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC; hepatoma). HCC may be focal, multifocal, or diffuse.

HCC receives the majority of its blood supply from branches of the hepatic artery. As a result, a characteristic pattern of early arterial enhancement and early washout is often seen on CT and MRI. This enhancement pattern may similarly be seen on contrast-enhanced ultrasound examinations.

L: uninvolved liver parenchyma; PV: portal vein

E) INCORRECT:

Biopsy of a hepatic hydatid cyst can result in anaphylaxis due to the release of the highly antigenic hydatid fluid. In an unruptured cyst, the echinococcal antigens evade the host's immune system; sudden exposure to hydatid fluid triggers a hyperacute immune reaction. Hepatic hydatid cyst can manifest as nonspecific abdominal pain, as seen in this patient, but ultrasonography would typically show a unilocular, anechoic, well-defined cyst with internal septa (spoke-wheel pattern), usually with daughter cysts floating within. Furthermore, this patient does not have any stated risk factors for Echinococcus infection (e.g., ingestion of contaminated food, travel to endemic region).
questions.hint: A well-demarcated, homogeneous, hyperechoic mass on liver ultrasound is consistent with cavernous hemangioma of the liver, the most common benign liver mass.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 2-month history of mild abdominal pain, nausea, and several episodes of vomiting. She often feels full after eating only a small amount of food. Abdominal examination shows mild right upper quadrant tenderness and a liver span of 16 cm. Ultrasonography shows a 5 x 4 cm hyperechoic mass in the left lobe of the liver. The mass is surgically excised. A photomicrograph of the resected specimen is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatocellular adenoma (HA) is a benign tumor of the liver that is typically seen in women aged 20–45 years. HA mainly occurs in individuals on long-term use of oral contraceptives or steroids. HA is usually asymptomatic and is often detected incidentally. On sonography, HA is seen as a well-demarcated, heteroechoic intraparenchymal lesion. Histopathological features of HA include enlarged benign hepatocytes that contain glycogen and lipid deposits, which are not seen in this specimen.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a biopsy from a hepatic nodule (H&E stain)

Sheets of hepatocytes arranged in two-cell thick cords are visible.
The cytoplasm of most hepatocytes is pale or clear, indicating intracytoplasmic glycogen accumulation.
There is no nuclear atypia.
The normal hepatic architecture of hexagonal lobules with a central vein and surrounding portal triads is absent.

This disorganized mass of benign hepatocytes is the characteristic histological appearance of a hepatocellular adenoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Alveolar echinococcosis is a rare parasitic infection that mostly affects the liver and causes intraparenchymal lesions. Hepatic lesions can manifest with upper abdominal pain and hepatomegaly, which are seen in this patient. Imaging would show anechoic cysts with or without septae and areas of calcification. On histopathology, the walls of echinococcal cysts are seen as lamellated membranes, surrounded by chronically inflamed hepatic parenchyma, and areas of calcification. Both of these features are absent in this specimen.

C) INCORRECT:

Most individuals (75–90%) with polycystic kidney disease (PKD) also have multiple hepatic cysts that typically manifest with right upper abdominal pain and hepatomegaly, which are seen in this patient. Unlike the specimen here, however, hepatic cysts in PKD are seen as multiple anechoic unilocular cysts on sonography, and histopathology would show cysts lined with cuboidal biliary epithelium and surrounded by normal hepatic parenchyma.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's biopsy specimen shows a benign vascular tumor, which confirms the diagnosis of cavernous hepatic hemangioma. Cavernous hemangioma of the liver is the most common benign hepatic tumor and is typically seen in women aged 30–50 years. While most patients with hepatic hemangiomas are asymptomatic, a large hepatic hemangioma can compress the adjacent bowel (causing early satiety) and stretch the Glisson capsule (causing upper abdominal pain). Because hepatic hemangiomas are highly vascular, they typically appear as hyperechoic masses on ultrasonography. Needle aspiration or biopsy should be avoided in the diagnostic workup of hepatic hemangiomas due to the risk of hemorrhage.
Image Description:

Ultrasound liver (transverse plane)

A homogeneous hyperechoic lesion (green overlay) with a well-defined margin and no hypoechoic halo can be seen. There is slight posterior acoustic enhancement (white area). This appearance is characteristic of a hemangioma.

Most hepatic hemangiomas are hyperechoic. However, they can appear hypoechoic, particularly when on a background of hyperechoic hepatic steatosis. If surrounded by a hypoechoic halo, a hyperechoic hepatic lesion must be considered suspicious for malignancy.

PV: hepatic portal vein

E) INCORRECT:

Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is a benign tumor of the liver that is typically seen in women aged 20–50 years. A large FNH tumor can cause hepatomegaly, abdominal pain, and early satiety, similar to the features seen in this patient. However, on imaging, FNH is seen as an intrahepatic mass of variable echogenicity, often with a central scar. In addition, a biopsy of FNH would show benign hepatocytes arranged in nodules. These nodules would be separated by fibrous septa containing aberrant blood vessels. Bile ductules and Kupffer cells would also be seen.
Image Description:

Histopathological liver section (Elastica van Gieson stain): circumscribed, central local scar, which appears as a central region of connective tissue (S). The surrounding liver parenchyma shows nodular changes (L) and resembles cirrhotic tissue.

F) INCORRECT:

Hepatic angiosarcoma is a rare tumor of the liver that is typically seen in men > 60 years of age who have been exposed to arsenic, vinyl chloride, or thorium dioxide. Hepatic angiosarcoma can manifest with upper abdominal pain, early satiety, and hepatomegaly, which are seen in this patient, but usually also causes weight loss, fatigue, or ascites. Unlike the specimen here, hepatic angiosarcoma usually appears as multiple large intraparenchymal lesions with necrotic areas on sonography. Histopathology would show vascular spaces lined with dysplastic endothelium that infiltrates the hepatic cords and sinusoids.

G) INCORRECT:

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) is the most common primary liver cancer. While HCC can manifest with upper abdominal pain, early satiety, and hepatomegaly, the most important risk factor for HCC is chronic liver disease (e.g., liver cirrhosis, chronic hepatitis B, chronic hepatitis C, hemochromatosis), which this patient does not have. On sonography, HCC appears as an intraparenchymal mass of variable echogenicity with areas of necrosis and calcification. Histopathology would show pleomorphic hepatocytes with eosinophilic cytoplasm, prominent nucleoli, and mitotic figures, as well as areas of necrosis and neovascularization, which is not consistent with this patient's biopsy findings.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a liver tissue specimen (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

The cancerous tissue (border indicated by green line) features tumor cells with granular eosinophil cytoplasm and nuclear pleomorphism (examples indicated by green arrow and green overlay). Adjacent to the neoplasm is a portal field (border indicated by red dashed line) with fibrosis, minimal inflammation, and an inconspicuous bile duct (red overlay). Normal liver tissue is not depicted here.

This is the appearance of moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma.
questions.hint: The photomicrograph shows numerous cystic spaces lined by a single layer of endothelium. The cysts contain erythrocytes and multiple thromboses. There is no evidence of normal hepatic parenchyma.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of right upper quadrant abdominal pain that radiates to her right shoulder. She describes her pain as 7 out of 10 in intensity. During the past 6 months, she has had similar episodes that typically occur after meals and are associated with nausea and vomiting. Medical history is unremarkable. Her temperature is 36.6°C (97.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 132/80 mm Hg. Results of laboratory studies, including a complete blood count and liver function tests, are within the reference ranges. Her pain resolves in the emergency department while waiting for an abdominal ultrasound. The ultrasound shows gallstones in the neck of the gallbladder without pericholecystic fluid, gallbladder wall thickening, or biliary ductal dilation. A sonographic Murphy sign is negative. The ultrasound also shows a well-circumscribed, homogenous, hyperechoic mass measuring up to 4 cm in diameter in the right lobe of the liver. A triphasic CT scan shows peripheral nodular enhancement in the arterial phase with centripetal filling during the portal venous and delayed phases. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Transarterial embolization (TAE) can be performed to decrease the size of large HHs (>10 cm) prior to surgical resections. This patient has an asymptomatic, 4-cm HH; therefore, neither surgery nor preoperative embolization is indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Transcutaneous biopsy of an incidental liver mass is performed if the diagnosis remains unclear after contrast-enhanced imaging or if the patient has an increased risk of liver malignancy (e.g., cirrhosis, extrahepatic malignancy). However, this patient's ultrasound and triphasic CT findings are diagnostic of HH. A biopsy is contraindicated in patients with HH, as it may cause bleeding.

C) INCORRECT:

Emergency cholecystectomy is indicated in the case of acute cholecystitis with complications (e.g., gangrenous cholecystitis, gallbladder perforation, emphysematous cholecystitis). Although this patient has symptomatic cholelithiasis, she has no signs and symptoms of acute cholecystitis, such as fever, leukocytosis, or positive Murphy sign. Also, sonographic signs of gallbladder inflammation (e.g., gallbladder thickening) or perforation are absent.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection of HHs may be considered in symptomatic patients and those with fast-growing or large HHs (> 10 cm). Because this patient has a 4-cm HH that does not cause symptoms (e.g., early satiety, persistent abdominal pain), surgery is not indicated at this time.

E) CORRECT:

HH is the most common benign liver tumor in women between the ages of 30–50 and is usually an incidental finding on imaging. This patient has a small (≤ 5 cm), asymptomatic HH that can be treated conservatively with observation and regular follow-up. Patients with larger lesions (> 5 cm) should undergo contrast-enhanced imaging 6–12 months after diagnosis to confirm the stability of the lesion. Surgical intervention may be considered for those with fast-growing or large HHs (> 10 cm) or lesions that cause persistent symptoms such as abdominal discomfort, early satiety, and nausea.

Additionally, this patient has symptomatic cholelithiasis, which requires elective cholecystectomy.
Image Description:

Ultrasound liver (transverse plane)

A homogeneous hyperechoic lesion (green overlay) with a well-defined margin and no hypoechoic halo can be seen. There is slight posterior acoustic enhancement (white area). This appearance is characteristic of a hemangioma.

Most hepatic hemangiomas are hyperechoic. However, they can appear hypoechoic, particularly when on a background of hyperechoic hepatic steatosis. If surrounded by a hypoechoic halo, a hyperechoic hepatic lesion must be considered suspicious for malignancy.

PV: hepatic portal vein
questions.hint: This patient's incidental liver finding has characteristic features of hepatic hemangioma (HH).

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman is seen for follow-up after CT performed for intermittent pain in the right upper quadrant revealed a 5.5-cm well-defined mass in the right hepatic lobe with arterial enhancement and absence of central scar. The patient denies nausea, vomiting, jaundice, and weight loss. She has no history of liver disease. Her medications include an oral contraceptive and a multivitamin. She has no family history of liver disease or gastrointestinal malignancy.
On examination, her abdomen is soft and nontender, and there is no evidence of hepatosplenomegaly.
Laboratory results are as follows:



Patient value
Reference range


Alanine aminotransferase (U/liter)
15
0–35


Aspartate aminotransferase (U/liter)
20
0–35


Alkaline phosphatase (U/liter)
60
30–120


Total bilirubin (mg/dL)
0.5
0.3–1.0


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Many liver lesions can be diagnosed on the basis of patient history and imaging characteristics alone, without the need for biopsy.

In a young woman without a history of underlying liver disease or malignancy, this liver mass is likely to be benign in nature. Hepatic adenomas are benign lesions most commonly found in premenopausal women taking oral contraceptives. They are usually solitary in nature and located in the right hepatic lobe. Affected patients often present with upper abdominal pain or discomfort, but many are asymptomatic and the mass is incidentally found during imaging for unrelated reasons. Hepatic adenomas carry a risk of rupture (particularly during pregnancy) and rare malignant transformation, and hepatic resection is generally recommended, especially for lesions that are > 5 cm or symptomatic. Because hepatic adenomas tend to bleed during percutaneous liver biopsy or fine-needle aspiration, these procedures are not recommended in the evaluation of hepatic adenomas.

Key learning point: If a premenopausal woman taking an oral contraceptive presents with a focal, painful liver mass, the most likely diagnosis is hepatic adenoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Hepatocellular carcinoma typically develops in patients with chronic liver disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is also a benign lesion that occurs in women age 20 to 50 years. However, FNH is usually <3 cm, asymptomatic, and not clearly associated with oral contraceptive use. On imaging, FNH has a characteristic central scar. Unlike hepatic adenomas, FNH does not have malignant potential and has a very low risk of rupture.

D) INCORRECT:

In nodular regenerative hyperplasia, multiple regenerative nodules develop in the liver in the absence of fibrosis. The condition is rare and is associated with underlying myeloproliferative disease, rheumatologic disorders, and use of some medications.

E) INCORRECT:

Metastatic liver disease is usually characterized by multiple lesions, rather than a solitary lesion.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with intermittent right upper quadrant discomfort for three months to the clinic. She has been taking combined oral contraceptives for eight years and denies smoking, alcohol use, abdominal trauma, or recent weight changes. Vital signs are stable. Physical examination reveals mild right upper quadrant tenderness with no palpable masses. Laboratory evaluation shows normal liver function tests (see reports).

Abdominal ultrasound: 4.5 cm lesion in the right lobe of the liver
Contrast-enhanced CT scan: Hepatic adenoma with no evidence of malignant transformation or hemorrhage

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Continue oral contraceptive agents and obtain MRI in 6 months

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatic adenomas are linked to estrogen exposure from oral contraceptives. Continuing these agents can promote adenoma growth and increase the risk of complications. While follow-up imaging is important, discontinuing oral contraceptives is crucial to reduce hormonal stimulation and encourage potential regression of the adenoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Imaging has confirmed the diagnosis of a hepatic adenoma, making biopsy unnecessary. Biopsy carries risks, including hemorrhage due to the lesion's vascular nature. The imaging findings are specific, and the patient's history of oral contraceptive use supports the diagnosis, eliminating the need for tissue sampling.

C) CORRECT:

Hepatic adenomas are benign liver lesions often associated with prolonged estrogen exposure from oral contraceptives. Estrogen promotes hepatocellular proliferation, contributing to adenoma growth. For lesions under 5 cm without hemorrhage or malignant transformation, discontinuing oral contraceptives is the initial management step. This reduces hormonal stimulation, potentially leading to tumor stabilization or regression and decreasing the risk of complications such as hemorrhage or malignant transformation.

Key learning point: In patients with hepatic adenomas associated with oral contraceptive use, the first step in management is to stop the oral contraceptive, as this can lead to regression of the adenoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical resection is typically reserved for hepatic adenomas ≥5 cm, those with rapid growth, or those with complications like hemorrhage. This patient's adenoma is 4.5 cm, with no signs of hemorrhage or malignant transformation, and she presents with stable vital signs and mild symptoms. Immediate surgical resection is unnecessarily aggressive given the current lesion size and clinical findings.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with acute onset right upper quadrant pain after lifting heavy boxes. She takes oral contraceptives and denies fever or nausea. Vital signs are normal. CT shows a 6-cm heterogeneous liver lesion with early arterial enhancement, no delayed contrast retention, and areas of hypodensity concerning for active hemorrhage. Laboratory studies show normal liver enzymes and CBC. What is the most appropriate disposition?

choices.text: Discharge with analgesia and hepatology follow-up
Discharge with instructions to repeat imaging in 6 months
Discharge with instructions to discontinue oral contraceptives and primary care follow-up
Admit for MRI and percutaneous biopsy
Admit for observation and surgical consultation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Outpatient hepatology follow-up would be inappropriate for a large hepatocellular adenoma with imaging findings concerning for hemorrhage and acute symptom onset, as this represents a potential surgical emergency requiring inpatient evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

Outpatient management with delayed imaging would be inappropriate given the acute presentation, large lesion size, and imaging findings suggesting possible hemorrhage.

C) INCORRECT:

While discontinuing oral contraceptives is appropriate long-term management for hepatocellular adenoma, primary care follow-up would be inadequate for managing a large hepatocellular adenoma with acute presentation and imaging findings concerning for hemorrhage.

D) INCORRECT:

Additional imaging and percutaneous biopsy are not the first priority when clinical presentation and CT findings in a young woman on oral contraceptives suggest hepatocellular adenoma, particularly in a patient with imaging findings concerning for hemorrhage.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – The imaging features suggest hepatocellular adenoma with possible hemorrhage in a woman taking oral contraceptives. The acute onset of pain combined with the large size (>5 cm) and imaging findings concerning for bleeding warrant hospital admission for observation and surgical consultation, as these lesions carry significant risk of rupture and life-threatening hemorrhage.
